item.title: Lance Armstrong Responds to USADA Allegation - Lance Armstrong
item.description: Lance responds to USADA allegation http://t.co/x0IEuGux
item.content:encoded: Lance responds to USADA allegation http://t.co/x0IEuGux AUSTIN, TX -- June 13, 2012 -- I have been notified that USADA, an organization largely funded by taxpayer dollars but governed only by self-written rules, intends to again dredge up discredited allegations dating back more than 16 years to prevent me from competing as a triathlete and try and strip me of the seven Tour de France victories I earned. These are the very same charges and the same witnesses that the Justice Department chose not to pursue after a two-year investigation. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: lancearmstrong.com

item.content:encoded: #TeamFollowBack Map Reveals 64 Drone Bases on American Soil http://t.co/kElglFE1 We like to think of the drone war as something far away, fought in the deserts of Yemen or the mountains of Afghanistan. item.title: U.S. Military Wants Drones in South America, But Why? | Danger Room | Wired.com
item.description: U.S. Military Wants Drones in South America, But Why?: Flying, spying robots are addictive. Every military comma... http://t.co/MugWnpKe
item.content:encoded: U.S. Military Wants Drones in South America, But Why?: Flying, spying robots are addictive. Every military comma... http://t.co/MugWnpKe Flying, spying robots are addictive. Every military commander who has them wants more. Those who don't have them covet their colleagues' supply. And according to Air Force planning, they're about to go to the military's redheaded, drone-poor stepchild: the command overseeing South America. The reasoning? They'll get back to you on that. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: wired.com

There’s a marketing principle called “the paradox of choice.” Essentially, more than 2 c... http://t.co/t4X4DuLJ
item.content:encoded: Brogan: Pick a Badge: There’s a marketing principle called “the paradox of choice.” Essentially, more than 2 c... http://t.co/t4X4DuLJ There’s a marketing principle called “the paradox of choice.” Essentially, more than 2 choices means people will be more inclined to do nothing. We do great with “this or that,” but not great with “here are five options.” Sure, we can do it, but it’s not a native mental Link - Trackbacks

item.title: Chicago Teachers Union Demands 30 Percent Pay Raise
item.description: Chicago Teachers Union Demands 30 Percent Pay Raise http://t.co/FbptLeoy
item.content:encoded: Chicago Teachers Union Demands 30 Percent Pay Raise http://t.co/FbptLeoy It takes a lot of nerve to ask for a 30 percent pay raise. You’d better be sure you had a banner year. Yet in Chicago, where just 15 percent of fourth graders are proficient in reading (and just 56 percent of students graduate), the teachers union is set to strike if the district does not agree to a 30 percent increase in teachers’ salaries. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: heritage.org

item.title: Morning Bell: Auto Bailout Was Really Just a UAW Bailout
item.description: Morning Bell: Auto Bailout Was Really Just a UAW Bailout: President Obama told the United Auto Workers (UAW) in ... http://t.co/N0IBJumV
item.content:encoded: Morning Bell: Auto Bailout Was Really Just a UAW Bailout: President Obama told the United Auto Workers (UAW) in ... http://t.co/N0IBJumV New research from Heritage shows taxpayers will lose $23 billion on the auto bailout and none of these losses came from saving jobs. The Obama Administration redistributed $26.5 billion more to the UAW than it would have received had it been treated as it usually would in bankruptcy proceedings. Taxpayers lost between $20 billion and $23 billion on the auto programs. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: heritage.org
